question.text: A dilute aqueous solution of <math><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></math> is electrolysed using platinum electrodes. The product at the anode and cathode are

solution.text: During the electrolysis of aq. <math><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> is evolved at the cathode as <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mo>.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mo>.</mo></mrow></msub></math> of sodium (-2.71 V) is much lower than that of water (-0.83 V) while <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> is evolved at the anode as <math><msub><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">0</mi></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mo>.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mo>.</mo></mrow></msub></math> potential of <math><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>-</mo></mrow></msup></math> ion (-0.2 V) is much more than that of water (-1.23 V).
